title: From sundowners to stargazing: a locals’ guide to Northern Ireland – in pictures

images.caption:
Discover a secret cascade in Antrim
Although one of Northern Ireland’s lesser-known National Trust sites, locals gush praise on Glenoe Waterfall, 18 miles north of Belfast. ‘It’s such a beautiful, powerful waterfall,’ says photographer Paul McIlwaine. ‘The native deciduous trees create a lush backdrop in summer and a spectacular show of colour in autumn. The waterfall is just a few metres from the car park, too, making it easy to get to for families with small children – or anyone like me who isn’t keen on a half-day hike.’

View Down with a difference
‘Many tourists tend to tackle Slieve Donard, the highest peak of the Mourne mountains, but there are endless, lesser-trekked routes in the range – for all levels,’ says Brendan Carty, director of Killowen Distillery. ‘I love the Slieve Binnian trail; a seven-mile loop with incredible Irish Sea and Silent Valley views. It’s a trail you can enjoy either as a solo hike or on a guided trek with local experts such as Walk the Mournes.’

Enjoy a sundowner in Portstewart
Northern Ireland’s coastline basks in some of the longest summer evenings in the UK, with the sunsets at Portstewart Strand offering a canvas to inspire. ‘We’re really spoilt for beautiful beaches, but Portstewart Strand – with its walk from the prom along the cliff – is a favourite,’ says artist and north coast native, Sara O’Neill. ‘After your stroll, Harry’s Shack makes one of the best spots to enjoy a beautiful sunset. The food is great and the deck is perfect for music and sundowners.’

Shoot for the stars in Tyrone
Tyrone is renowned for its rolling countryside and rugged Sperrin mountains, but this year the county’s dark sky allure is in the spotlight. ‘I’d really recommend a visit to our newest attraction, the OM Dark Sky Park & Observatory in the Davagh Forest,’ says Mary Anne Mackle, owner of nearby Wee Buns cookery school. ‘Whether viewing from a telescope, or just the naked eye, you can observe everything from meteors to even the Northern lights thanks to Tyrone’s unpolluted night skies.’

Meander Belfast’s Maritime Mile
Belfast’s Maritime Mile offers visitors a deep-dive into the city’s cultural and culinary highlights. ‘It’s an open-air museum,’ says Norman Trotter, director of Belfast City Bike Tours. ‘You have world-class attractions like Titanic Belfast – the liner was built in the city – and HMS Caroline, quirky art such as the Big Fish, and a vibrant food scene. Grab a local beer, cider or hearty Irish stew at the historic American Bar or savour a seafood lunch or sumptuous afternoon tea at Titanic Hotel Belfast.’

Climb Armagh’s legendary mountain
For Armagh tour guide Donna Fox, a trip to the mystical mountain of Slieve Gullion is hard to beat. ‘Follow in the footsteps of Finn the Giant to the summit and be rewarded with spectacular views and a rich tapestry of colours – yellow gorse, purple heather and orange bracken, blended into the lush green landscape. And if you’ve worked up an appetite, you can refuel at Johnny Murphy’s traditional pub at the foot of the mountain.’
images.credit: Photograph: Design Pics Inc/Getty Images/Design Pics RF

images.caption:
Take a fresh view of the Giant’s Causeway
‘The Giant’s Causeway is designated a world heritage site by Unesco for good reason,’ says Flip Robinson, tour guide at Giant Tours Ireland. ‘The hexagonal columnar basalt rocks are an otherworldly must-see along the already breathtaking Causeway Coastal Route. To avoid the crowds, take the Cliff Path trail down the Shepherd’s Steps to view the Causeway from above and then descend via the Organ Pipes. This approach provides amazing impact with an incredible story to tell of giants, ice and fire.’

Reach heavenly heights in Fermanagh
‘Not too many mountains have a stairway to the top,’ explains Barry Flanagan, owner of Erne Water Taxi. ‘Apart from incredible summit views, the accessibility of Cuilcagh mountain makes it so special.’ A one-mile boardwalk across protected bogland – plus 450 steps – soar visitors to ‘peak Fermanagh’ and the highest point of the Marble Arch Caves Global Geopark. ‘It makes what can be a daunting activity much more tangible and enjoyable,’ says Flanagan.
